facts.text: Disputes between Noor Khan and Pratap and his brothers about a well in village Mundara. Noor Khan claimed half share purchase, Pratap claimed exclusive property, several court proceedings.
On September 29, 1960 at about 2:00 p.m., Noor Khan accompanied by father Samdu Khan and eight others went to Pratap's field with farm, house, stable, disputed well, called for possession of well.
Pratap declined possession, Samdu Khan fired muzzle-loading gun at Ganesh (Pratap's brother) but missed. Noor Khan then fired at Pratap killing him instantaneously.
Other members of Noor Khan's party at instigation of Samdu Khan beat Ganesh, Prabhu, Mohan, Gulab (Pratap's brothers) with sticks and weapons causing injuries.
After assailants retired, Ganesh lodged complaint against 15 persons including Noor Khan and Samdu Khan at police station Bali.
Ten accused arrested and tried before Additional Sessions Judge, Sirohi for rioting, unlawful assembly, causing death of Pratap and injuries.
Noor Khan charged substantively for causing Pratap's death by gunshot.
Sessions Judge acquitted all accused, holding prosecution story unreliable: no independent witnesses, alterations in story, false involvement due to enmity.
State appealed to Rajasthan High Court in D.B. Criminal Appeal No. 407 of 1961.
High Court set aside acquittal of Noor Khan, convicted under s.302 IPC, sentenced to life imprisonment; confirmed acquittal of others. Judgment dated November 9, 1962.
Pratap died from gunshot injury; post-mortem by Dr. Mehta: wound of entry, left lung lacerated by metal pieces.
Dr. Mehta examined injured on October 1, 1960: Prabhu - two contusions, one incised; Ganesh - three contusions; Mohan - one contusion; Gulab - swelling; all ~48 hours old.
Eye-witnesses Prabhu, Ganesh, Mohan, Gulab deposed Noor Khan fired fatal shot at Pratap; they injured in same incident.
Story corroborated by female witnesses Bhanwari and Mathura.
FIR named persons not present (e.g. Narpat Singh, Pratap Singh, Kesia Choudhary, Sheonath Singh) due to enmity.

Investigating officer Hari Singh made jottings/notes of witness statements on 29-09-1960, not detailed; later dictated to head-constable Kapuraram who prepared statements without witnesses present; jottings destroyed.
Copies of Kapuraram's statements supplied to accused; witnesses denied parts in cross-exam.

legal_issues.text: Whether the High Court was justified in reversing the Sessions Judge's order of acquittal and convicting Noor Khan under s.302 IPC.
Whether failure of investigating officer to record and supply proper statements under s.161 CrPC vitiates the trial and occasions failure of justice.

petitioner_arguments.text: Prosecution story unreliable: no independent witnesses, alterations, false involvement of persons due to enmity; Sessions Judge correctly acquitted.
Discrepancies: only one shot fired though both armed with guns; distance estimates (20 ft+) inconsistent with medical (4 ft); sequence of firing varied.
Accused deprived of s.161 statements: investigating officer made only jottings destroyed later; Kapuraram's statements not true records, witnesses denied parts; vitiates trial.

respondent_arguments.text: Injuries on four eye-witnesses (Ganesh, Prabhu, Mohan, Gulab) corroborate presence at 2:00 p.m. on 29-09-1960; medical timing matches.
Testimony of Bhanwari, Mathura, Mohan Singh reliable; Noor Khan fired from ~4 ft near Peepal tree; discrepancies minor, do not affect core case.
High Court has full power to review acquittal evidence per Sheo Swarup; gave weight to trial judge but injuries assure presence.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: ss.417, 423 CrPC; Sheo Swarup v. King Emperor

respondent_arguments.text: Improper statements irregularity, no prejudice; s.537 CrPC cures unless failure of justice.

court_reasoning.text: Injuries on four family members improbable from other incident; assure presence at scene; corroborates testimony despite no independents expected at site/time.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Presence of injured eye-witnesses established beyond doubt.

court_reasoning.text: Discrepancies in FIR names, sequence of firing, distance estimates minor; illiterate villagers' estimates unreliable; topography (Peepal tree ~8 ft from Ora) consistent with 4 ft firing range.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Faulty distance estimates do not discredit core story.

court_reasoning.text: s.161 does not mandate recording, but if done, copies must be supplied; here jottings destroyed, Kapuraram statements not true s.161 records; improper but not vitiating unless prejudice.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Breach per s.537 cured absent failure of justice.

court_reasoning.text: No prejudice shown: contradictions minor (e.g. extra names, non-essential acts); no objection on jottings nature; High Court analysed evidence carefully.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No substantial infirmity; uphold High Court.

holdings.text: High Court justified in reversing acquittal; Noor Khan guilty under s.302 IPC; injuries, topography, reliable witnesses prove firing from close range.
Failure to supply true s.161 statements irregularity under s.537 CrPC; does not vitiate trial without prejudice to accused.

precedents_cited.relevance: High Court full power to review acquittal evidence under ss.417,423 CrPC, giving weight to trial judge.
Valuable right under s.162 for contradiction; breach grave but prejudice must be inferred case-by-case.

precedents_cited.case_name: Narayan Rao v. State of Andhra Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Failure under ss.173(4), 207A(3) directory, not vitiating unless prejudice.
Nagpur view on s.161 breach; rejected as misinterpreting ss.161,162.
Similar to Baliram; evidence not inadmissible.
s.162 right valuable; caution if prejudice, but not inadmissible.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Substantive offence of murder committed by Noor Khan.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Investigation statements, supply to accused, High Court appeal powers, curing irregularities absent prejudice.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal by special leave, upheld Rajasthan High Court's conviction of Noor Khan under s.302 IPC and sentence of life imprisonment, finding no prejudice from procedural irregularities and evidence reliable.

key_quotes.text: It is highly improbable that all these witnesses who were members of the same family suffered injuries... in some other incident... and then conspired to bear false testimony.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Failure to furnish statements... may not vitiate the trial... breach thereof must be considered in the light of the prejudice caused to the accused... s.537 CrPC.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The right given to an accused person by this section [162] is a very valuable one and often provides important material for cross examination.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quoting Pulukuri Kotayya on s.162 value.
